text: Anicius Manlius Severinus Boethius, commonly called Boethius (; also Boetius ; 477 â€“ 524 AD), was a Roman philosopher. He was from the important Roman Anicia family, which included the Roman Emperors Petronius Maximus and Olybrius.Hodgkin, Thomas. Italy and Her Invaders. London: Adamant Media Corporation, 2001. In 510 Boethius became consul in the kingdom of the Ostrogoths. He was put in prison and later executed, by King Theodoric the Great, who thought he was secretly working with the Byzantine Empire. In prison, Boethius wrote the Latin philosophy book Consolation of Philosophy. In the Middle Ages, it was a famous and important book.The Consolation of Philosophy (Oxford World's Classics), Introduction (2000) ==References== Category:477 births Category:524 deaths Category:Ancient Roman writers Category:Ancient Roman philosophers
